title:

quoteFirst: The discrepancies respecting the number slain on the part of the victors, form a striking contrast to the accuracy of the account of the loss of their enemies. The English writers vary in their statements from
quoteLast: hundred, whilst the French chroniclers assert that from three hundred to sixteen hundred individuals fell on that occasion. St. Remy and Monstrelet assert that sixteen hundred were slain. --_Nicolas’s History of Agincourt.
title:
King Henry V
Arranged for Representation at the Princess's Theatre
author: Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616; Kean, Charles John, 1811?-1868 [Editor]

quoteFirst: It was Mopus's year, when the Yorkshire Lass ran a dead heat with Skyrocket for the Diddlesworth. I stood
quoteLast: , in thousands! think of that,--seventeen thousand pounds to one against the filly. It was thought so good a thing that Naylor--old Jerry, as they used to call him--offered me a clean thousand to let him take half the wager.
title: One Of Them
author: Lever, Charles, 1806-1872; Browne, Hablot Knight, 1815-1882 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Considering this engagement in all its details and with all its attendant circumstances, remembering that Forsyth’s party, including himself, numbered all told but fifty-one men, and that the Indians numbered about
quoteLast: , this fight was one of the most remarkable and at the same time successful contests in which our forces on the Plains have ever been engaged; and the whole affair, from the moment the first shot was fired until the beleaguered party was finally relieved by Colonel Carpenter’s command, was a wonderful exhibition of daring courage, stubborn bravery, and heroic endurance, under circumstances of greatest peril and exposure.
title: My life on the plains
author: Custer, George A. (George Armstrong), 1839-1876

quoteFirst: The moon rises on the 15th at 12:39 a. m.; and sets on the 1st and 31st at 12:30 and
quoteLast: , respectively. On the 16th at 11:00 a. m., nearest the earth; on the 28th, at 5:30 p. m., farthest from the earth. Its greatest elevation, 67° 4′, occurs on the 15th, and its least, 29° 50.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: The exterior planets, which are further removed from the Sun, are very considerably larger, have a density five times less, more than twice as great a velocity in the period of their rotation round their axes, are more compressed at the poles, and if six satellites may be ascribed to Uranus, have a quantitative preponderance in the number of their attendant moons, which is as
title: Cosmos: A Sketch of the Physical Description of the Universe, Vol. 1
author: Humboldt, Alexander von, 1769-1859; Otté, E. C. (Elise C.), 1818-1903 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The phases for the month are as follows: Last quarter, 7th, at 9:34 a. m.; new moon, 15th, at
quoteLast: ; first quarter, 21st, at 6:12 p. m.; full moon, 29th, at 1:06 a. m. Rises on the 1st, at 8:38 p. m.; sets on the 16th, at 8:28 p. m.; rises on the 30th, at 8:21 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, April 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: The township of Rio, which, as I was told, is but a small part of the Capitanea, or province, is said to contain 37,000 white persons, and 629,000 blacks, many of whom are free; making together 666,000 in the proportion of
quoteLast: . The Indians, who are employed to do the King’s work in this neighbourhood, can scarcely be considered as inhabitants; their residence is at a distance, from whence they come by turns to their task, which they are obliged to perform for a small pay. The guard-boat was constantly rowed by these people, who are of a light copper colour, and have long black hair.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. I. Being the First of the First Voyage.
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Banks, Joseph, 1743-1820 [Contributor]; Hawkesworth, John, 1715?-1773 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The township of Rio, which, as I was told, is but a small part of the capitanea, or province, is said to contain 37,000 white persons, and 629,000 blacks, many of whom are free; making together 666,000, in the proportion of
quoteLast: . The guard-boat was constantly rowed by these people, who are of a light copper colour, and have long black hair.
title:
A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 12
Arranged in Systematic Order: Forming a Complete History of the

author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: From calculations founded on the documents last introduced into the house, it appeared that, at present, the proportion of American to foreign tonnage employed in the American trade was, with Spain as sixteen to one, Portugal
quoteLast: , Netherlands twenty-six to one, Denmark fifteen to one, Russia fourteen to one, France between four and five to one, and Great Britain one to three.
title:
The Life of George Washington, Vol. 5
Commander in Chief of the American Forces During the War
which Established the Independence of his Country and First
President of the United States
author: Marshall, John, 1755-1835
